{{Multiple issues| {{primary sources|date=March 2018}} {{Globalize/US|date=February 2018}} }}
'''Civic technology''', or '''civic tech''' for short, is technology that enables engagement, participation or enhances the relationship between the people and government by enhancing citizen communications and public decision, improving government delivery of service, and infrastructure.<ref>{{cite web|title=Civic Tech: Entrepreneurship Opportunities|url=http://codeforamerica.org/startups/civic-entrepreneurship-2014/|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140727043407/http://codeforamerica.org/startups/civic-entrepreneurship-2014/|archivedate=2014-07-27|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Nick Bilton: New York Times: Changing Government and Tech With Geeks|url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/07/06/changing-government-and-tech-with-geeks/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=1}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=But What Is "Civic"?|url=http://civichall.org/civicist/what-is-civic/}}</ref> It encompasses mainly [[information technology]] and includes [[civic application]]s, platforms supporting government bodies, institutions and other software that enables those goals. Civic technology has had increasing promise and importance with time. In the [[Information Age]], digital communications have become the foundation for political and economic exchanges.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mandarano|first=Lynn|year=2011|title=Building Social Capital in the Digital Age of Civic Engagement|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Lynn_Mandarano/publication/256548552_Building_Social_Capital_in_the_Digital_Age_of_Civic_Engagement/links/55fc10c908aeba1d9f3aaf1e.pdf|journal=Journal of Planning Literature|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> As advanced technologies have become commonplace in society and available throughout the population, many local governments and officials have begun utilizing them for public outreach and feedback. Specifically, the [[Internet]] is being used more for communication between governing officials and citizens.
==Definition==
There are four different types of e-government services and civic technology falls within the category of government-to-citizen (or G2C), the other categories include government-to-business (G2B), government-to-government (G2G), and government-to-employees (G2E).<ref name=":10" />
A 2013 report from the [[Knight Foundation]], an American non-profit, attempts to map different focuses within the civic technology space.<ref name=":5" /> It broadly categorizes civic technology projects into two categories: open government and community action.<ref name=":5">{{cite web|url=http://knightfoundation.org/features/civictech/|title=Knight Foundation: Trends in Civic Tech|publisher=}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" |+ !Open government, includes: !Community action, includes: |- |[[Open data|Data access]] and transparency |Peer-to-peer local sharing |- |Voting |Civic [[crowd-funding]] |- |Visualization and mapping |Neighborhood forums |- |Data utility |Information [[crowdsourcing]] |- |Resident feedback |Community organizing |- |Public decision making | |} Within the [[Knight Foundation]], they "care about ensuring that people have access to the news and information that they need to lead their lives in a democracy." <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.knightfoundation.org/articles/building-better-democracy-civic-tech|title=Knight Foundation|website=www.knightfoundation.org|access-date=2016-12-08}}</ref> They seek to establish a precedent of accessibility to information and the sharing of these sources for the common benefit of the people. With this accessibility, they enable for a more transparent, open system of sharing information for the benefit of more insightful, informed users and citizens that can engage more often in political and social matters that pertain to their concerns and to their lives.
Citizens are also now given access to their representatives through social media. They are able to express their concerns directly to government officials through sites like [[Twitter]] and [[Facebook]]. There have even been past cases of online voting being a polling option for local elections, which have seen vastly increased turnouts, such as in an Arizona election in 2000 which saw a turnout double that of the previous election. It is asserted though that civic technology in government provides for a good management technique but lacks in providing fair democratic representation.<ref name="cavanaugh2000">{{cite journal | last = Cavanaugh | first = John W. | date = 2000 | title = E-Democracy: Thinking About The Impact Of Technology On Civic Life | url = http://web.b.ebscohost.com/ehost/detail/detail?sid=fd12d636-c362-4d16-bf21-b8e4e7ef98af%40sessionmgr112&vid=39&hid=123&bdata=JmxvZ2luLmFzcCZzaXRlPWVob3N0LWxpdmU%3d#AN=3792349&db=f6h | journal = National Civic Review | volume = 89 | issue = 3 | pages = 229 | accessdate = 2015-11-21 | doi=10.1002/ncr.89305 }} </ref> [[Social media]] is also becoming a growing aspect of government, towards furthering the communication between the government and its citizenry and towards greater transparency within the governmental sectors.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Criado|first=J. Ignacio|last2=Sandoval-Almazan|first2=Rodrigo|last3=Gil-Garcia|first3=J. Ramon|date=2013-10-01|title=Government innovation through social media|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0740624X1300083X|journal=Government Information Quarterly|volume=30|issue=4|pages=319–326|doi=10.1016/j.giq.2013.10.003}}</ref> This innovation is facilitating a change towards a more progressive and open government, based on civic engagement and technology for the people. With social media as a communicating platform, it enables the government to provide information to the constituents and citizens on the legislative processes and what is occurring in the [[United States Congress|Congress]], for the sake of the citizens' concerns with the government procedures.
The definition of what constitutes civic technology is contested to a certain extent,<ref name="brookings.edu">{{cite web|url=http://www.brookings.edu/blogs/techtank/posts/2015/04/20-civic-technology|title=The future of civic technology|publisher=}}</ref> especially with regards to companies engaged in the [[sharing economy|sharing]] or [[access economy]], such as [[Uber (company)|Uber]], [[Lyft]], and [[Airbnb]]. For example, AirBnb's ability to provide New York residents with housing during the aftermath of Superstorm Sandy could be considered a form of civic technology.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.airbnb.com/disaster-response|title=Airbnb Disaster Response|publisher=}}</ref> However, Nathaniel Heller, Managing Director of the Research for Development Institute's Governance Program contends that for-profit platforms definitively fall outside of the scope of civic technology: Heller has said that "while citizen-to-citizen sharing is indeed involved, the mission of these companies is focused on maximizing profit for their investors, not any sort of experiment in building social capital."<ref>[https://www.globalintegrity.org/2013/12/the-sharing-economy-is-not-civic-tech/ The Sharing Economy is Not Civic Tech]</ref> From a goal perspective, civic technology can be understood as “the use of technology for the public good”.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://blogs.microsoft.com/on-the-issues/2016/04/27/towards-taxonomy-civic-technology/#sm.000001n0mhkt1p4e0ytqgdi7vu1qn|title=Towards a taxonomy of civic technology - Microsoft on the Issues|date=2016-04-27|newspaper=Microsoft on the Issues|access-date=2016-11-28}}</ref>
Microsoft's Technology & Civic Engagement Team have attempted to produce a precise taxonomy of civic technology through a bottom-up approach.<ref name=":6" /> They inventoried the existing initiatives and classified them according to: * their functions * the social processes they involved * their users and customers * the degree of change they sought * the depth of the technology. Microsoft's Civic Graph is guiding the developing network of civic innovators, expanding "its visualizations of funding, data usage, collaboration and even influence" <ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=http://www.govtech.com/Microsoft-Civic-Graph-Charts-the-New-World-of-Civic-Tech.html|title=Civic Graph Charts the New World of Civic Tech|website=www.govtech.com|access-date=2016-12-07}}</ref> It is a new tool that is opening up the access to track the world of civic technology towards improving the credibility and progress of this sector. This graph will enable more opportunities for access by governmental institutions and corporations to discover these innovators and use them for progressing society towards the future of technology and civic engagement. To create an informed and insightful community, there needs to be a sense of civic engagement in this community, where there is the sharing of information through civic technology platforms and applications.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.knightfoundation.org/articles/civic-technology-needs-community-engagement-order-work|title=Knight Foundation|website=www.knightfoundation.org|access-date=2016-12-08}}</ref> "Community engagement applied to public-interest technology requires that members of a community participate." <ref name=":2" /> With communal participation in civic tech platforms, this enables more informed residents to convene in a more engaged, unified community that seeks to share information, politically and socially, for the benefit of its citizenry and their concerns.This work resulted in a [https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1FzmvVAKOOFdixCs7oz88cz9g1fFPHDlg0AHgHCwhf4A/edit#gid=291660636 field guide].
The Technology & Civic Engagement Team have also produced a network visualization tool for civic technology organizations, [http://civicgraph.io/ Civic Graph].
Technology that is designed to benefit the citizenry places the governments under pressure "to change and innovate the way in which their bureaucracies relate to citizens." <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bonsón|first=Enrique|last2=Torres|first2=Lourdes|last3=Royo|first3=Sonia|last4=Flores|first4=Francisco|date=2012-04-01|title=Local e-government 2.0: Social media and corporate transparency in municipalities|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0740624X1200010X|journal=Government Information Quarterly|volume=29|issue=2|pages=123–132|doi=10.1016/j.giq.2011.10.001}}</ref> E-government initiatives have been established and supported in order to strengthen the democratic values of governmental institutions, which can include [[Transparency in government|Transparency]], along with improving the efficiency of the legislative processes to make the government more accountable and reactive to citizens' concerns. These will further civic engagement within the political spectrum for the sake of greater [[Direct representation]] and a more democratic political system.
=== Worldwide === A worldwide organization for civic tech is the [[Open Government Partnership]] (OGP). It “is a multilateral initiative that aims to secure concrete commitments from governments to promote transparency, empower citizens, fight corruption, and harness new technologies to strengthen governance.”<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.opengovpartnership.org/|title=Open Government Partnership|website=Open Government Partnership|accessdate=2016-11-10}}</ref> Created in 2011 by eight founding governments (Brazil, Indonesia, Mexico, Norway, the Philippines, South Africa, the United Kingdom and the United States), the OGP gathers every year for a summit. Countries involved are located mainly in America (North and South), Europe and South-Asia (Indonesia, Australia, South Korea). Only a few African countries are part of the OGP, though South Africa is one of the founding countries.
Technological progress is rampant throughout the nations of the world, but there are dividing efforts and adoption techniques in how rapid certain countries are progressing compared to others.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Corrales|first=Javier|last2=Westhoff|first2=Frank|date=2006-01-01|title=Information Technology Adoption and Political Regimes|journal=International Studies Quarterly|volume=50|issue=4|pages=911–933|doi=10.1111/j.1468-2478.2006.00431.x|jstor=4092785}}</ref> How countries are able to use information pertains to how devoted nations are to integrating technology into the lives of their citizens and businesses. Local and national governments are funding tens of billions of dollars towards information technology, for the sake of improving the functions and operations of this technology to work for the people and the governments.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/mikemontgomery/2015/06/24/why-civic-tech-is-the-next-big-thing/#21ffa203e24b|title=Why Civic Tech Is The Next Big Thing|last=Montgomery|first=Mike|newspaper=Forbes|access-date=2016-12-07}}</ref> With more governments attaining a grasp on these technologies, it is paving the way towards more progressive and democratic political systems, for the concerns of future society and for those of the citizens of these nations.
== Civic technology in Africa ==
=== Burkina Faso ===
==== Government-led initiatives ==== The government of Burkina Faso has a government website portal offering citizens online information about the government structure, their constitution, and laws.<ref name=":10">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s2fnBQAAQBAJ&dq|title=E-Government: Implementation, Adoption and Synthesis in Developing Countries|last=Bwalya|first=Kelvin J.|last2=Mutula|first2=Stephen M.|publisher=Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co KG|year=2014|isbn=3110305275|location=|pages=31-32|via=Google Books}}</ref>
=== Kenya ===
==== Citizen-led initiatives ==== Launched in Kenya in 2014,<ref name=":7" /> "MajiVoice" is a joint initiative by the Water Services Regulatory Board (WASREB- the Water Sector Regulator in Kenya)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.majivoice.com/?page=Introduction%20to%20MajiVoice|title=About MajiVoice - Introduction to MajiVoice|last=|first=|date=|website=www.majivoice.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref> and the World Bank's Water and Sanitation Program.<ref>http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/632501467986270596/pdf/93637-BRI-2012Nov1-P126637-P096367-Kenya-WSP-Box-385404B-PUBLIC.pdf</ref> As opposed to walk-in complaint centers, the initiative enables Kenyan citizens to report complaints with regards to water services via multiple channels of technology. The platform allows for communication between citizens and water service providers with the intention to improve service delivery in impoverished areas and user satisfaction. Users are given four options to report their water complaints. They can dial a number and report a complaint, send a text message (SMS) through their cell phone, or login to an online portal through a web browser on their phone or their laptop.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.majivoice.com/?page=Send%20Complaint%20or%20Feedback|title=How it Works - Send Complaint or Feedback|last=|first=|date=|website=www.majivoice.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref> One evaluation highlights the citizen engagement achieved after its implementation, from 400 complaints a month to 4000 complaints, and resolution rates from 46 percent to 94 percent<ref name=":7" />
=== South Africa ===
==== Government-led initiatives ==== The South African government has a website portal for citizens called www.gov.za - this was created by Center for Public Service Innovation (CPSI) in partnership with the Department of Public Service and Administration and the State Information Technology Agency.<ref name=":10" /><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ar0HcSxUSX0C&dq|title=The Innovative CIO and E-participation in E-government Initiatives|last=Obi|first=Toshio|publisher=IOS Press|year=2010|isbn=1607505045|location=|pages=212-213|via=Google Books}}</ref> The government portal allows the citizens to interact with their government and provide feedback, request forms online, as well as access online to laws and contact information for lawmakers.<ref name=":10" />
=== Uganda ===
==== Government-led initiatives ==== The Ugandan government has a website portal created for citizens called Parliament Portal, which gives citizens online access to laws, their constitution, and election related news.<ref name=":10" />
==== Citizen-led initiatives ==== U- Report, a mobile platform introduced by UNICEF Uganda in 2011,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.centreforpublicimpact.org/case-study/unicef-ureport/|title=UNICEF’s U-Report: using mobile technology for youth participation in policymaking - Centre for Public Impact (CPI)|last=|first=|date=|work=Centre for Public Impact (CPI)|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref> is an initiative that runs large scale polls with Ugandan youth on a wide range of issues, ranging from safety to access to education to inflation to early marriage. The goal of the initiative was to have Ugandan youth play a role in civic engagement within the context of local issues.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Tiago|first=Peixoto,|last2=L.|first2=Sifry, Micah|date=2017-08-21|title=Civic Tech in the Global South|url=https://openknowledge.worldbank.org/handle/10986/27947?locale-attribute=en}}</ref> U-Report is still active (as of April 2018), with over 240,000 users across Uganda. Support for the initiative primarily came from the aid of the government, NGO's, youth organizations, faith based organizations, and private companies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.unicef.org/uganda/voy.html|title=UNICEF Uganda - Youth - U-report|last=|first=|date=|website=www.unicef.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref> Users sign up for the program for free by sending a text on their phone, then every week "U-Reporters" answer a question regarding a public issue. Poll results are published in public media outlets such as newspapers, radio, etc. UNICEF takes these responses and provides members of parliament (MP's) a weekly review of these results, acting as a bridge between government and Ugandan youth.<ref name=":7" />
== Civic technology in Asia ==
=== Taiwan ===
==== Citizen-led initiatives ==== The vTaiwan (v for virtual) was created initially by members of the open source community and later as a collaboration with the Taiwan's government.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://civichall.org/civicist/vtaiwan-democracy-frontier/|title=vTaiwan: Public Participation Methods on the Cyberpunk Frontier of Democracy|last=Barry|first=Liz|website=civichall.org|accessdate=2017-06-03}}</ref> They use a conversation tool called pol.is that leverages machine learning to scale online discussion.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blog.pol.is/pol-is-in-taiwan-da7570d372b5|title=pol.is in Taiwan|last=Megill|first=Colin|website=blog.pol.is|accessdate=2017-06-03}}</ref>
== Civic technology in Oceania ==
=== Australia ===
==== Citizen-led initiatives ====
In Australia, a platform and proposed political party called MiVote<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mivote.com.au/|title=MiVote|website=MiVote|accessdate=2017-04-28}}</ref> has a mobile app for citizens to learn about policy and cast their vote for the policies they support.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3063379/can-direct-democracy-be-revived-through-new-voting-apps|title=Can Direct Democracy Be Revived Through New Voting Apps?|website=Fast Company|accessdate=2017-04-28}}</ref> MiVote politicians elected to office would then vote in support of the majority position of the people using the app.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.afr.com/news/politics/mivote-wants-to-bring-remote-control-politicians-to-the-senate-20170411-gvicfe|title=MiVote wants to bring remote control politicians to the Senate|website=The Australian Financial Review|accessdate=2017-04-28}}</ref>
== Civic technology in Europe ==
=== Denmark ===
==== Government-led initiatives ==== In 2002 [[MindLab]], an innovation public sector service design group was established by the Danish ministries of Business and Growth, Employment, and Children and Education.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://ssir.org/articles/entry/design_led_innovation_in_government |title=Design-Led Innovation in Government|last=Bason|first=Christian|date=2013|work=Stanford Social Innovation Review (SSIR)|access-date=2018-02-24|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|publisher=Stanford University}}</ref> MindLab was the one of the world's first public sector design innovation labs and their work inspired the proliferation of similar labs and user-centered design methodologies deployed in many countries worldwide.<ref name="thegovlab">{{Cite news|url=http://thegovlab.org/mindlab-the-evolution-of-a-public-innovation-lab/|title=MindLab: The evolution of a public innovation lab - The Governance Lab @ NYU|date=2016-03-07|work=The Governance Lab @ NYU|access-date=2018-02-24}}</ref> The design methods used at MindLab are typically an iterative approach of [[rapid prototyping]] and testing to evolve not just their government projects, but also government organizational structure using ethnographic-inspired user research, creative ideation processes, and visualization and modeling of service prototypes.<ref name=":1" /><ref name="thegovlab" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://hbr.org/2014/11/look-to-governmentyes-governmentfor-new-social-innovations|title=Look to Government—Yes, Government—for New Social Innovations|date=2014-11-20|work=Harvard Business Review|access-date=2018-02-24}}</ref> In Denmark, design within the public sector has been applied to a variety of projects including rethinking [[Copenhagen|Copenhagen's]] waste management, improving social interactions between convicts and guards in Danish prisons, transforming services in [[Odense]] for mentally disabled adults and more.<ref name=":1" />
=== Estonia === In 2013 the online platform People's Assembly (Rahvakogu)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://rahvakogu.ee/in-english/|title=People’s Assembly|website=rahvakogu.ee|accessdate=2017-07-12}}</ref> was launched for crowdsourcing ideas and proposals to amend Estonia's electoral laws, political party law, and other issues related to democracy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.citizens.is/portfolio/estonian-laws-changed/|title=Rahvakogu, Estonia – From ideas to laws|publisher=Citizens Foundation}}</ref>
=== France === The most dynamic French city regarding civic tech is [[Paris]], with many initiatives moving in the [[Sentier]], a neighborhood known for being a tech hub.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.liberation.fr/evenements-libe/2016/09/08/paris-bientot-capitale-des-civic-tech_1489773 |title=Paris, bientôt capitale des Civic Tech ?|newspaper=Libération.fr|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref> According to [[Le Monde]], French civic tech is “already a reality” but lacks investments to scale up.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/economie/article/2016/10/10/les-nouvelles-ambitions-de-la-civic-tech-francaise_5010742_3234.html|title=Les nouvelles ambitions de la " Civic Tech " française |last=Fagot |first=Vincent|date=2016-10-10|newspaper=Le Monde.fr|language=fr|issn=1950-6244|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
==== Government-led initiatives ==== In France, public data are available on data.gouv.fr<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.data.gouv.fr/fr/|title=Accueil - Data.gouv.fr |website=www.data.gouv.fr|accessdate=2016-11-10}}</ref> by the Etalab<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.etalab.gouv.fr/|title=Le blog de la mission Etalab, Service du Premier Ministre chargé de l'ouverture des données publiques et du développement de la plateforme française OpenData|last=|first=|date=|website=www.etalab.gouv.fr|publisher=Office of the Prime Minister, within the Interministerial Directorate for the Digital and Information and Communication System of the State, Government of France|language=French|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2016-11-10}}</ref> mission, located under the authority of the Prime Minister.
Government agencies are also leading large citizen consultation through the Conseil national du numérique<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://cnnumerique.fr/|title=Conseil National du Numérique|website=Conseil National du Numérique|language=fr-FR|accessdate=2016-11-10}}</ref> (National digital council), for example with the law about the digital republic (Projet de loi pour une république numérique).
==== Citizen-led initiatives ==== The French citizen community for civic tech is gathered in the collective Démocratie ouverte<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://democratieouverte.org/|title=Démocratie Ouverte - Collectif de transition démocratique|website=democratieouverte.org |accessdate=2016-11-10}}</ref> (Open democracy). The main purpose of this collective is to enhance democracy to increase citizen power, improve the way to decide collectively and update the political system. Démocratie ouverte gathers many projects focused on understanding politics, renewing institutions, participating in democracy, and public action. Several open-source, non-profit web platforms have been launched nationwide to support citizen's direct involvement: Communecter.org,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.communecter.org|title=Réseau sociétal citoyen|last=pixelhumain|website=www.communecter.org|access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> Demodyne.org<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.demodyne.org|title=DEMODYNE - Shape Your Society|last=Niculita |first=Desvigne, Dobre,|date=|website=www.demodyne.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref> as well as Democracy OS France (derived from the Argentinian initiative).
LaPrimaire.org organizes open primaries to allow the French to choose the candidates they wish to run for public elections<ref>{{cite web |title=LaPrimaire|url=https://laprimaire.org/|website=LaPrimaire|access-date=21 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Guerrini |first1=Federico |title=Civic Tech Platform La Primaire Wants To Help French Voters Bypass Traditional Parties |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/federicoguerrini/2016/05/31/disgusted-french-voters-turn-to-technology-to-find-an-independent-candidate-for-the-next-elections|website=Forbes|accessdate=17 December 2016}}</ref>
=== Iceland ===
The [[Icelandic constitutional reform, 2010–13]] instituted a process for reviewing and redrafting their constitution after the 2008 financial crisis, using social media to gather feedback on twelve successive drafts.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/technology/future_tense/2014/07/five_lessons_from_iceland_s_failed_crowdsourced_constitution_experiment.html|title=We, All of the People|last=Landemore|first= Hélène|website=slate.com|accessdate=2017-06-03}}</ref>
Beginning in October 2011, a [[Citizens Foundation]] platform called Betri Reykjavik<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://betrireykjavik.is|title=Betri(Better)Reykjavik|website=BetriReykjavik|accessdate=2017-04-28}}</ref> had been implemented for citizens to inform each other and vote on issues.<ref>{{Cite book|author = Gnarr, Jón|title = Gnarr! How I Became the Mayor of a Large City in Iceland and Changed the World |url = https://www.mhpbooks.com/books/gnarr/|year = 2014|publisher = Melville House|isbn = 9781612194134|pages = 192}}</ref> Each month the city council formally evaluates the top proposals before issuing an official response to each participant.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/303599164_Better_Reykjavik_-_Open_Municipal_Policymaking|title=Better Reykjavik — Open Municipal Policymaking |last=Lackaff|first= Derek|website=researchgate.net|accessdate=2018-05-28}}</ref> As of 2017, the number of proposals approved by the city council reached 769.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.ft.com/content/754a9442-af7b-11e7-8076-0a4bdda92ca2|title=The world watches Reykjavik’s digital democracy experiment |last=Jacobs|first=Joshua|website=ft.com|accessdate=2018-05-28}}</ref>
The [[Pirate Party (Iceland)]] uses the crowdsourcing platform Píratar<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://x.piratar.is/polity/1/|title=Píratar|website=x.piratar.is|accessdate=2017-07-12}}</ref> for members to create party policies.
=== Italy ===
==== Citizen-led initiatives ==== A consortium made by TOP-IX,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.top-ix.org/|title=TOP-IX|website=TOP-IX|accessdate=2016-11-16}}</ref> FBK<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fbk.eu/|title=FBK|website=Fondazione Bruno Kessler|access-date=2016-11-16}}</ref> and RENA<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.progetto-rena.it/|title=progetto RENA|website=Progetto RENA|accessdate=2016-11-16}}</ref> created the Italian civic tech school.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tecnologieciviche.eu |title=Scuola di tecnologie civiche |accessdate=2016-11-16}}</ref>
The first edition<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tecnologieciviche.eu/prima-edizione/|title=civic tech school 1st|accessdate=2016-11-16}}</ref> was in May 2016 in Turin.
The [[Five Star Movement]] has a tool called Rousseau<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://rousseau.movimento5stelle.it/|title=Rousseau|website=rousseau.movimento5stelle.it|accessdate=2017-07-12}}</ref> which gives members a way to communicate with their representatives.
=== Spain ===
The Madrid City Council has a department of Citizen Participation<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://commonstransition.org/this-is-how-people-power-wins-an-election-the-story-of-ahora-madrid//|title=This Is How People Power Wins an Election: The Story of Ahora Madrid|website=Commons Transition|accessdate=2017-04-28}}</ref> that facilitates a platform called Decide Madrid for registered users to discuss topics with others in the city, propose actions for the City Council, and submit ideas for how to spend a portion of the budget on projects voted on through [[participatory budgeting]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://decide.madrid.es/mas-informacion?locale=en/|title=More Information|website=Decide Madrid|accessdate=2017-04-28}}</ref>
[[Podemos (Spanish political party)]] uses a reddit called Plaza Podemos<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.reddit.com/r/podemos/|title=Plaza Podemos|website=reddit.com|accessdate=2017-07-12}}</ref> where anybody can propose and vote on ideas.
=== Sweden ===
The City of Stockholm has a make-a-suggestion page on stockholm.se and available as an app, allowing citizens to report any ideas for improvement in the city along with a photo and GPS. After receiving a suggestion, it is sent to the appropriate office that can place a work order. During 2016, one hundred thousand requests were recorded. This e-service began in September 2013.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://international.stockholm.se/governance/smart-and-connected-city/how-the-smart-city-develops/|title=How the smart city develops|website=stockholm.se|accessdate=2017-07-19}}</ref>
The city government of [[Gothenburg]] has an online participatory voting system,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://goteborg.se/wps/portal/start/kommun-o-politik/sa-kan-du-paverka/goteborgsforslaget/goteborgsforslaget/lamna-e-forslag/|title=Göteborgsförslaget||website=goteborg.se|accessdate=2017-07-19}}</ref> open for every citizen to propose changes and solutions. When a proposal receives more than 200 votes, it is delivered to the relevant political committee.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.shareable.net/blog/12-reasons-why-gothenburg-is-an-amazing-sharing-city|title=12 Reasons Why Gothenburg is an Amazing Sharing City |last=Kollaborativ Ekonomi Göteborg|website=shareable.net|accessdate=2017-07-19}}</ref>
=== United Kingdom ===
==== Government-led initiatives ==== In 2007 and 2008 documents from the British government explore the concept of "user-driven public services" and scenarios of highly personalized public services.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200708/cmselect/cmpubadm/410/410.pdf|title=User Involvement in Public Services, Sixth Report of Session|last=|first=|date=2008-05-07|website=Public Administration Select Committee, The House of Commons, London: The Stationery Office Limited|access-date=2018-02-23}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20100304125017/http://www.cabinetoffice.gov.uk/media/cabinetoffice/strategy/assets/building.pdf|title=Policy Review, Building on progress: Public services|last=|first=|date=March 2007|website=Prime Minister’s Strategy Unit|access-date=2018-02-23}}</ref> The documents proposed a new view on the role of service providers and users in the development of new and highly customized public services, utilizing user involvement.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" /> This view has been explored through an initiative in the UK. Under the influence of the European Union, the possibilities of service design for the public sector are being researched, picked up, and promoted in countries such as Belgium.<ref>Thoelen and Cleeren (ed.), Public Service Design. A guide for the application of service design in public organisations, 2015 http://designvlaanderen.be/publicatie/public-service-design</ref>
[[Care Opinion]] was set up to strengthen the voice of patients in the [[NHS]] in 2005. [[Behavioural Insights Team|Behavioural Insights Team (BIT)]] (also known as Nudge) was originally part of the UK cabinet and was founded in 2010, in order to apply [[nudge theory]] to try to improve UK government policy, services and save money. As of 2014, BIT became a decentralized, semi-privatized company with [[Nesta (charity)]], BIT employees and the UK government each owning a third of this new business.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-26030205|title='Nudge unit' privatisation unveiled|date=2014-02-05|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-02-24}}</ref> That same year a Nudge unit was added to the United States government under president Obama, referred to as the ‘US Nudge Unit,’ working within the [[Office of Science and Technology Policy|White House Office of Science and Technology Policy]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://thepsychreport.com/politics/executive-order-formally-establishes-us-nudge-unit/|title=Executive Order Formally Establishes US 'Nudge Unit’|last=|first=|date=2015-09-16|work=Behavioral Scientist|access-date=2018-02-24|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
==== Citizen-led initiatives ==== [[FixMyStreet.com|FixmyStreet]].com is a website and app developed by [[mySociety]], a UK based civic technology company that works to make online democracy tools for UK citizens. FixmyStreet allows citizens in the United Kingdom to report public infrastructure issues (such as potholes, broken streetlights, etc.) to the proper local authority.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fixmystreet.com/|title=FixMyStreet|last=|first=|date=|website=FixMyStreet|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref> FixmyStreet became inspiration to many countries around the world that followed suit to use civic technology to better public infrastructure.<ref name=":7" /> The website was funded by the Department for Constitutional Affairs Innovation fund and created by mySociety.<ref>https://spir.aoir.org/index.php/spir/article/viewFile/16/18</ref> Along with the platform itself, mySociety released [[FixMyStreet|FixmyStreet]], a free and open-source software framework that allows users to create their own website to report street problems.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://github.com/mysociety/fixmystreet/blob/master/LICENSE.txt|title=mysociety/fixmystreet|last=|first=|date=|website=GitHub|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref> mySociety has many different tools, like parliamentary monitoring ones, that work in many countries for different types of governance. When such tools are integrated into government systems, citizens can not only understand the inner workings of their now transparent government, but also have the means to "exert influence over the people in power".<ref>{{cite web|last1=mySociety|title=Democracy|url=https://www.mysociety.org/democracy|website=mySociety|accessdate=17 December 2016}}</ref> Newspeak House is a community space and venue focused on building a community of civic and political technology practitioners in the United Kingdom.<ref>{{cite web|title=Newspeak|url=https://nwspk.com/|website=Newspeak|accessdate=7 June 2018}}</ref>
[[Spacehive]] is a crowdfunding platform for civic improvement projects that allows citizens and local groups to propose project ideas such as improving a local park or starting a street market.<ref>https://spacehive.com</ref>{{Better source|date=November 2018}} Projects are then funding by a mix of citizens, companies and government bodies. The platform is used by several councils including the Mayor of London to co-fund projects.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.london.gov.uk/what-we-do/regeneration/funding-opportunities/crowdfund-london|title=Crowdfund London|last=|first=|date=|website=London City Hall|publisher=Greater London Authority|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-28}}</ref>
=== Ukraine ===
==== Government-led initiatives ==== In [[Ukraine]], major civic tech movement started out with open data reform in 2014. As for now, public data are available on data.gov.ua, national open data portal.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://data.gov.ua|title=Open Data in Ukraine - data.gov.ua |website=www.data.gov.ua|accessdate=12 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Can open data grow Ukraine's economy by 1-Billion In 7 years|url=https://theodi.org/article/can-open-data-grow-ukraines-economy-by-1-billion-in-7-years/|website=The ODI|accessdate=12 July 2018}}</ref>
==== Citizen-led initiatives ==== Some widely used Ukrainian civic tech projects are donor recruitment platform DonorUA, Ukrainian companies' data and court register monitoring service Open Data Bot, participatory budgeting platform "Громадський проект". The latter accounts for over 3 million users.<ref>{{cite web|title=DonorUA: How the Synergy of the Civil Society, Business and IT Saves Thousands of Lives |url=https://medium.com/@1991CTC/donorua-how-the-synergy-of-the-civil-society-business-and-it-saves-thousands-of-lives-6ae76813f766|website=Medium|accessdate=12 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Open Data Bot|url=https://opendatabot.com/en|website=Open Data Bot|accessdate=12 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The First Forum on Participatory Budgeting Held in Kyiv |url=https://www.ibser.org.ua/en/news/first-forum-participatory-budgeting-held-kyiv|website=IBSER|accessdate=12 July 2018}}</ref>
In 2017, to foster the growth of civic tech initiatives, Ukrainian NGO [[SocialBoost]] launched 1991 Civic Tech Center, a dedicated community space in country's capital, [[Kyiv]]. The space opened following a $480,000 grant from [[Omidyar Network]], the philanthropic investment firm established by [[eBay]] founder Pierre Omidyar.<ref>{{cite web|title=As Some Bail, Denis Gursky Sees Ukraine as Land of Opportunity, and Thinks You Should Too|url=http://www.atlanticcouncil.org/blogs/ukrainealert/as-some-bail-denis-gursky-sees-ukraine-as-land-of-opportunity-and-thinks-you-should-too|website=Atlantic Council|accessdate=12 July 2018}}</ref>
== Civic technology in North America ==
=== Canada ===
==== Government-led initiatives ==== [[Canadian Digital Service|Canadian Digital Service (CDS)]] was launched in 2017, as part of an attempt to bring better IT to the Canadian government.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ottawa/canadian-digital-service-recruiting-it-brains-prevent-phoenix-1.4445010|title=Canadian Digital Service takes startup approach to building better IT for government|last=Ireton|first=Julie|date=2017-12-14|work=CBC|access-date=2018-11-14|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":8">{{Cite news|url=https://publictechnology.net/articles/features/inside-canadian-digital-service-%E2%80%93-how-transformation-agency-began-life-%E2%80%98-corner|title=Inside the Canadian Digital Service – how the transformation agency began life ‘on the corner of someone’s desk’|last=Trendall|first=Sam|date=2018-08-01|work=PublicTechnology.net|access-date=2018-11-14|language=en}}</ref> The CDS was established within the Treasury Board of Canada the Canadian agency that oversees spending within departments and the operations of the public service.<ref name=":8" /> Scott Brison, the president of the Canadian Treasury Board, launched CDS and was Canada’s first minister of digital government.<ref name=":8" />
==== Citizen-led initiatives ====
As in other countries, the Canadian civic technology movement is home to several organizations. Code for Canada is a non-profit group, following somewhat the model of [[Code for America]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sawhney|first1=Gabe|title=It’s time for Code for Canada|url=https://medium.com/code-for-canada/its-time-for-code-for-canada-88ffe2ab2c2a|website=Medium|publisher=Code for Canada|accessdate=27 September 2017}}</ref> Several cities or regions host civic technology groups with regular meetings (in order from West to East): Edmonton,<ref>{{cite web|title=Beta City YEG|url=https://betacity.ca|website=Beta City YEG|publisher=Beta City YEG|accessdate=27 September 2017}}</ref> Waterloo Region,<ref>{{cite web|title=CivicTechWR|url=https://civte.ch|website=CivicTechWR|publisher=CivicTechWR|accessdate=27 September 2017}}</ref> Toronto,<ref>{{cite web|title=Civic Tech Toronto|url=http://civictech.ca|website=Civic Tech Toronto|publisher=Civic Tech Toronto|accessdate=27 September 2017}}</ref> Ottawa<ref>{{cite web|title=Ottawa Civic Tech|url=http://yowcivictech.ca|website=Ottawa Civic Tech|publisher=Ottawa Civic Tech|accessdate=27 September 2017}}</ref> and Fredericton.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.civictechfredericton.com/|title=CIVIC TECH FREDERICTON|website=CIVIC TECH FREDERICTON|access-date=2018-02-07}}</ref>
=== United States ===
==== Government-led initiatives ====
The Clinton, Bush, and Obama administrations sought initiatives to further openness of the government, through either increased use of technology in political institutions or efficient ways to further civic engagement.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/John_Bertot/publication/268424264_Engaging_the_Public_in_Open_Government_Social_Media_Technology_and_Policy_for_Government_Transparency/links/54d49c6b0cf2970e4e635529.pdf|title=Engaging the Public in Open Government: Social Media Technology and Policy for Government Transparency|last=Bertot|first=John Carlo|date=August 12, 2010|website=Researchgate.net |publisher=ResearchGate |access-date=October 23, 2016}}</ref> The Obama administration pursued an [[Open Government Initiative]] based on principles of transparency and civic engagement.<ref name="ejp">{{Cite web|url=http://unpan1.un.org/intradoc/groups/public/documents/UN-DPADM/UNPAN046727.pdf|title=Open data: an international comparison of strategies|last=Huijboom|first=Noor|date=March–April 2011|website=epracticejournal.edu|publisher=European Journal of Practice|access-date=October 23, 2016}}</ref> This strategy has paved the way for increased governmental transparency within other nations to improve democratically for the citizens' benefit and allow for greater participation within politics from a citizen's perspective. During his run for president, Obama was "tied directly to the extensive use of social media by the campaign." <ref>{{Cite journal |last=Bertot |first=John Carlo|last2=Jaeger|first2=Paul T.|last3=Hansen|first3=Derek|date=2012-01-01|title=The impact of policies on government social media usage: Issues, challenges, and recommendations|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0740624X11000992|journal=Government Information Quarterly|volume=29|issue=1|pages=30–40|doi=10.1016/j.giq.2011.04.004}}</ref>
According to a study conducted by the [[International Data Corporation]] (IDC), an estimated $6.4 billion will be spent on civic technology in 2015 out of approximately $25.5 billion that governments in the United States will spend on external-facing technology projects.<ref name="brookings.edu" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.techrepublic.com/article/civic-tech-in-2015-6-9-billion-to-connect-citizens-to-services-and-to-one-another/|title=Civic tech in 2015: $6.4 billion to connect citizens to services, and to one another - TechRepublic|publisher=}}</ref> A [[John S. and James L. Knight Foundation|Knight Foundation]] survey of the civic technology field found that the number of civic technology companies grew by roughly 23% annually between 2008 and 2013.<ref>[http://www.knightfoundation.org/media/uploads/publication_pdfs/knight-civic-tech.pdf The Emergence of Civic Tech: Investments in a Growing Field]</ref>
==== Citizen-led initiatives ====
Civic technology is built by a variety of companies, organizations and volunteer groups. One prominent example is [[Code for America]], a not-for-profit based in San Francisco, working toward addressing the gap between the government and citizens.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.codeforamerica.org/about-us|website=www.codeforamerica.org|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref> College students from [[Harvard University]] created the national non-profit [[Coding it Forward]] that creates data science and technology internships for undergraduate and graduate students in United States federal agencies.<ref>{{cite web |title=About |url=https://www.codingitforward.com/about/ |website=Coding it Forward |accessdate=30 August 2018}}</ref> Another example of a civic technology organization is the Chi Hack Night,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://chihacknight.org/|title=Chi Hack Night|website=Chi Hack Night|accessdate=2016-11-10}}</ref> based in Chicago. The Chi Hack Night is a weekly, volunteer-run event for building, sharing and learning about civic technology. Civic Hall<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://civichall.org/|title=Civic Hall|website=Civic Hall|accessdate=2017-06-03}}</ref> is a coworking and event space in New York City for people who want to contribute to civic-minded projects using technology.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/annefield/2015/02/09/a-coworking-site-for-civic-tech-in-new-york-city/#59a9e60b6c96|title=A Coworking Site For Civic Tech In New York City|last=Field|first=Anne|website=forbes.com|accessdate=2017-06-03}}</ref> And [[OpenGov]] creates software designed to enable public agencies to make data-driven decisions, improve budgeting and planning, and inform elected officials and citizens.
OneBusAway, a mobile app that displays real-time transit info, exemplifies the open data use of civic technology. It is maintained by volunteers and has the civic utility of helping people navigate their way through cities. It follows the idea that technology can be a tool for which government can act as a society-equalizer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.govtech.com/civic/What-is-Civic-Tech.html|title=What is Civic Tech?|last=Wood|first=Colin|date=16 August 2016|website=govtech.com|publisher=e.Republic|access-date=15 December 2016}}</ref>
=== Mexico ===
==== Government-led initiatives ==== Within the Mexican president’s office, there is a national digital strategy coordinator who works on Mexico's national digital strategy.<ref name=":9">{{Cite web|url=https://www.mckinsey.com/business-functions/digital-mckinsey/our-insights/how-mexico-can-become-latin-americas-digital-government-powerhouse|title=How Mexico can become Latin America’s digital-government powerhouse|last=Cesar|first=Max|last2=Chaia|first2=Alberto|date=2018-11-01|website=McKinsey & Company|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-15|last3=de Oliveira Vaz|first3=Andre|last4=Garcia-Muñoz|first4=Gonzalo|last5=Haugwitz|first5=Philipp}}</ref> The office has created the gob.mx portal, a website designed for Mexican citizen to engage with their government, as well as a system to share open government data.<ref name=":9" /> According to [[McKinsey & Company]], in a 2018 survey Mexico had the worst-rated citizen experience (4.4 out of 10) for convenience and accessibility of Mexican government services, of the group of countries surveyed (Canada, France, Germany, Mexico, the United Kingdom, and the United States).<ref name=":9" />
==== Citizen-led initiatives ==== '''[[Arena Electoral]]''' was an online platform created by Fundación Ethos during the Mexican electoral process of 2012 to promote responsible voting.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://arenaelectoral.com/article/detail/18/|title=Bienvenidos|last=|first=|date=|website=Arena Electoral|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref> An online simulation was created by taking the four presidential candidates in that election cycle and each were given policy issues based on the Mexican national agenda that they had to come up with a solution to. Once each candidate gave their solutions, the platform published it on their website and left it to the Mexican citizens to vote for the best policy.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://vanguardia.com.mx/conestaherramientadescubreconcualcandidatoeresmasafin-1319495.html|title=Con esta herramienta, descubre con cuál candidato eres más afín|last=|first=|date=|work=Vanguardia|access-date=2018-04-19|language=es}}</ref>
== Civic technology in South America == {{Expand section|date=September 2018}}
=== Argentina ===
Partido de la Red ([[Net Party]]) is an Argentinean political party using the DemocracyOS open-source software with the goal of electing representatives who vote according to what citizens decides online.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://participedia.net/en/organizations/partido-de-la-red-net-party/|title=Partido de la Red|website=Participedia|accessdate=2017-04-28}}</ref>
==Effects of civic technology==
===Effects on social behavior and civic engagement===
Because of the conveniences provided by civic technology, there are benefits as well as growing concern about the effects it may have on social behavior and civic engagement.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://cyber.harvard.edu/publications/2013/why_we_engage|title=Why We Engage: How Theories of Human Behavior Contribute to Our Understanding of Civic Engagement in a Digital Era|last=Baldwin-Philippi|first=Jesse|last2=Balestra|first2=Martina|date=2013-10-27|website=Berkman Klein Center|publisher=Harvard University|access-date=2018-02-27|last3=Gordon|first3=Eric}}</ref> New technology allows for connectivity and new communications, as well as changing how we interact with issues and contexts beyond one's intimate sphere.<ref name=":0" /> Civic technology affords transparency in government with open-government data, and allows more people of diverse socioeconomic levels to be able to build and engage with civic matters in a way that was not possible prior.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/news/business/article199488089.html|title=‘Civic tech’ efforts open up government data for the great public good|last=|first=|date=2018-02-10|work=news and observer|access-date=2018-02-27|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
==== Communication ==== The importance of face-to-face interactions has also been called to question with the increase in e-mails and [[social media]] and a decrease in traditional, in-person social interaction. Technology as a whole may be responsible for this change in social norm, but it also holds potential for turning it around with audio and video communication capabilities. More research needs to be conducted in order to determine if these are appropriate substitutes for in-person interaction, or if any substitute is even feasible.<ref name="cavanaugh2000" />
Preece & Shneiderman discuss the important social aspect of civic technology with a discussion of the "reader-to-leader framework", which follows that users inform readers, who inform communicators, who then inform collaborators, before finally reaching leaders.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Preece|first=Jennifer|year=2009|title=The Reader-to-Leader Framework: Motivating Technology-Mediated Social Participation|url=http://www.cs.umd.edu/~ben/papers/Jennifer2009Reader.pdf|journal=Theory and Review|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> This chain of communication allows for the interests of the masses to be communicated to the implementers.
==== Elections ==== Regarding elections and online polling, there is the potential for voters to make less informed decisions because of the ease of voting. Although many more voters will turn out, they may only be doing so because it is easy and may not be consciously making a decision based on their own synthesized opinion. It's suggested that if online voting becomes more common, so should constituent-led discussions regarding the issues or candidates being polled.<ref name="cavanaugh2000" />
===Effects on socioeconomics===
With advanced technologies coming at higher costs and with an increased reliance on civic technologies may leave low-income families in the dark if they cannot afford the platforms for civic technology, such as [[computers]] and [[tablet computers|tablets]]. This causes an increase in the gap between lower and middle/high [[socioeconomic]] class families.<ref name="cavanaugh2000" />
Knowledge of how to use computers is equally important when considering factors of accessing civic technology applications online, and is also generally lower in low-income households. [[State school|Public Schools]] have taken the lead in ensuring proper technology access and education in the classroom to better prepare children for the high-tech world, but there is still a clear difference between online contributions from those with and without experience on the internet.<ref name="cavanaugh2000" />
==Future of civic technology==
As the field of civic technology advances further through the coming years it seems as though apps and handheld devices will become a key focus for development as more companies and municipalities reach out to developers to help with specific issues. Apps are being used in conjunction with hand held devices to make life easier. Tasks such as communication, data tracking, and safety are just a few of the topics app developers and communities have tried to make easier. The cheapest way for citizens to get help and information is through neighbors and others around them. By linking people through apps and websites that harbor conversation and promote civil service cities have found an inexpensive way to provide services to its people.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.govtech.com/dc/8-Cities-Showcase-Next-Civic-Tech-Apps-Initiatives.html|title=The Future of Civic Tech: 8 Localities Showcase Their Initiatives|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://content.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2026474_2026675_2039309,00.html|title=Intelligent Cities|first=Amy|last=Feldman|date=21 December 2010|publisher=|via=content.time.com}}</ref>
As civic technology is "just a piece of the $25.5 billion that government spends on external information technology (IT)," it is not difficult to see how this sector will grow from here on out towards fostering more innovation in the public and private sectors and towards furthering civic engagement within these sectors and with these platforms of technology.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.brookings.edu/blog/techtank/2015/04/20/the-future-of-civic-technology/|title=The future of civic technology {{!}} Brookings Institution|date=2016-12-07|newspaper=Brookings|access-date=2016-12-07}}</ref>
==Civic hacking== {{stub section|date=June 2016}} Civic hacking is a technological approach to solving civic problems, often involving the use of government data to make governments more accountable. Civic hackers can be programmers, designers, data scientists, good communicators, civic organizers, entrepreneurs and government employees.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://opengovdata.io/2014/civic-hacking/|title=Civic Hacking - Open Government Data: The Book}}</ref> Some civic hackers are employed by nonprofits, such as [[Code for America]] and projects such as [[mySociety]] work at the intersection of civic technology and [[hacktivism]].<ref name="WhatWeDo">{{cite web |title=What We Do |url=http://codeforamerica.org/what-we-do/ |accessdate=2011-01-15}}</ref><ref name="civ">{{cite news|title=Is Civic Hacking Becoming 'Our Pieces, Loosely Joined'?|url=http://techpresident.com/news/wegov/22617/civic-hacking-becoming-our-pieces-loosely-joined|publisher=Tech President|date=2012-07-25}}</ref> Some work for innovative for-profit companies, such as the geospatial software provider Azavea in Philadelphia. Others are civic hackers only by night.
=== Code for America === {{See also|Code for America}} Code for America is a [[non-partisan]], non-political [[501(c)(3)]] [[organization]] founded in 2009 to address the widening gap between the public and private sectors in their effective use of technology and design. The organization believes that for the U.S. government to truly serve the people in the 21st century, it must do three things: # Be good at digital. Digital skills must be embedded at all levels of government, and owned by the people responsible for delivering programs and services to the public. # Ensure policy and implementation work together, and are centered around the needs of the people. Linear processes, moving from policy, to implementation to stasis, must transform into iterative cycles where policy and implementation are informed by each other and are focused on people's needs. # Be a platform for civic engagement and participation. Government must learn to incorporate productive contributions from the public, so that everyone can help make government work.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.codeforamerica.org/how|title=How we do it - Code for America|last=America|first=Code for|newspaper=Code for America|access-date=2016-11-17}}</ref>
=== mySociety === {{See also|MySociety}} mySociety is an [[e-democracy]] project of the [[UK]]-based [[Charitable organisation|registered charity]] named [[UK Citizens Online Democracy]].<sup>[[MySociety#cite note-ukcod-2|[2]]]</sup> It began as a UK-focused organisation with the aim of making online democracy tools for UK citizens.<sup>[[MySociety#cite note-beg-3|[3]]]</sup>
=== Princeton Group Hackings === Princeton University Professor [[Andrew Appel]] set out to prove how easy it was to hack into a voting machine. He and a graduate student, [[Alex Halderman]], purchased a voting machine, and Halderman picked the lock in 7 seconds. They removed the 4 [[ROM cartridge|ROM]] chips and replaced them with modified versions of their own: a version of modified firmware that could throw off the machine's results, subtly altering the tally of votes, never to betray a hint to the voter. It took less than 7 minutes to complete the process.
Appel wrote a testimony for the Congress House Subcommittee on Information Technology hearing on “Cybersecurity: Ensuring the Integrity of the Ballot Box”, suggesting to for Congress to eliminate touchscreen voting machines after the election of 2016, and that it require all elections be subject to sensible auditing after every election to ensure that the systems are functioning properly and to prove to the American people that their votes are counted as cast.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://oversight.house.gov/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/2016-09-28-Appel-Princeton-Testimony.pdf|title=Andrew Appel Princeton Testimony|last=Appel|first=Andrew|date=September 28, 2016|website=House Subcommittee of Information Technology|publisher=|access-date=November 17, 2016}}</ref>

{{Infobox television | show_name = Drinking Made Easy | image = | runtime = Approx. 30m | starring = [[Zane Lamprey]] | director = | editor = Travis Ford
Eric Grabowski | country = {{USA}} | network = [[AXS TV]] | picture_format = [[1080i]] ([[High-definition television|HDTV]]) | creator = | first_aired = October 6, 2010 | last_aired = present | num_seasons = 3 | num_episodes = 61 | list_episodes = List of Drinking Made Easy episodes | production_website = | website = http://www.drinkingmadeeasy.com/ }} '''''Drinking Made Easy''''' is a [[pub crawl|pub-crawl]] television series that premiered in 2010{{cite web|title=Internet Movie Database|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1699208/episodes}} and airs on [[AXS TV]] in the [[United States]]. Comedian [[Zane Lamprey]] hosts a humorous bus trip around the United States and [[Canada]], exploring the local drinking culture of various cities in the countries. In each episode, Lamprey samples popular or original cocktails and beers from bars and breweries in the area. Season two premiered with an hour long episode on October 5, 2011,{{cite tweet|user=drinkingmadeasy|author=Drinking Made Easy|number=108942517013188608|date=31 August 2011|title=It's official! Season two of Drinking Made Easy premiers with a one-hour episode on October 5th. Set your kegerators!}} on HDNet. ==Format== Each episode begins with an overview of the highlights of the episode. Throughout the show Zane and his friend Steve McKenna visit popular bars, breweries, and distilleries where they sample different offerings from the establishments. At bars, Zane is typically behind the bar interviewing the bartender, as well as making cocktails with the help of the bartender. At some point during the episode, McKenna (and sometimes Lamprey) will engage in an eating challenge where he attempts to eat a large portion of a signature dish from a restaurant in the area. Sometimes McKenna is trying to set a record at the restaurant, othertimes he and Zane are racing to finish first or eat the most. Another segment found only in season one is an interview led by Marc Ryan. He typically visits a brewery or distillery on his own, and tries to learn the history and story of the business, as well as sample what they produce. Zane and Steve hold a competition in each episode called the "Six Six-Pack Challenge" where Lamprey and McKenna face off in some sort of game and bet each other six six-packs on the outcome. The games are usually inspired by the location of the episode or the bars they visit. ==Cast== *'''Zane Lamprey''': Host. *'''Steve McKenna''': Sidekick to Zane Lamprey. He typically accompanies him to all of the bars and breweries, tries the drinks Zane mixes, and participates in the food challenge(season 1 only) and six six-pack challenge. *'''Marc Ryan''': Correspondent who does his own interviews. Only in season one. *'''Wes DuBois''': Wears the Pleepleus costume in each episode. ==Drinking game rules== The show also doubles as a drinking game, introduced after the first commercial break in each episode. The rules are as follows: #The first person to see Pleepleus in a shot can make someone else drink. #The first person to notice a continuity error can make someone else drink. #Whenever Zane and Steve compete during the show, pick a side. If you lose, you drink. #When Zane burps, the last person to make the "Good Burp" sign (putting your thumb to your forehead) has to drink. #When Marc touches someone the first person to say "touché" can make someone else drink. ==Eating Challenges (Only in Season 1)== In each episode Zane challenges Steve to an eating contest. This usually involves Steve trying to finish a restaurant's specialty or Zane racing Steve to eat the most of a certain food. The eating challenges were discontinued after the first season. Zane said the reason for this was because he had always won them, which made it unfair for Steve. {| class="wikitable" |- ! width="4%"| Episode ! width="7%"| Location ! {{for|the medical term|Entoptic phenomenon}}
In archaeology, the term '''entoptic phenomena''' relates to visual experiences derived from within the eye or brain (as opposed to externally, as in normal vision). In this respect they differ slightly from the medical definition, which defines entoptic phenomena as only applying to sources within the eye, not the brain. To avoid this confusion, the term '''subjective visual phenomena''' is sometimes used. ''Entoptic'' was chosen by author David Lewis Williams due to its origin from [[Greek language|Greek]] meaning "coming from within".<ref>Williams 2002, pp. 127</ref>
There has been a great deal of work trying to find evidence of motifs and compositions derived from entoptic phenomena in [[prehistoric art]], especially [[rock art]] and [[megalithic art]]. The justification of this research is that entoptic phenomena normally occur during [[Altered state of consciousness|states of altered consciousness]], the practice of which may impact our views of ancient religious and social practice. The importance of looking outside traditional methods of research for interpreting [[prehistoric]] cultures is made more so due to the lack of abundant data which makes current cultural studies viable. "Art and the ability to comprehend it are more dependent on kinds of mental imagery and the ability to manipulate mental images than on intelligence."<ref>Williams 2002, pp. 111</ref>
==David Lewis-Williams's system== ===Stage 1=== Experiences include [[geometric]] visual patterns such as dots, zagging lines, as well as grid patterns which are all common shapes which are universally understood by the human condition.<ref>Williams 2002, pp. 121</ref> These patterns and shapes can be seen without aid of [[psychotropic]] substances but under their influence the heightened effects precipitate modes of altered consciousness. Entoptic experiences differ from [[hallucination]]s in that they are a purely visual phenomenon, while hallucinations represent experience of culturally occurring themes as well as physical coming from the five senses.<ref>Williams 2002, pp. 127</ref>
===Stage 2=== Entoptic Phenomena are interpreted in ways that can be understood, matched to objects or ideas that may be familiar in day-to-day life and may also be attributed to the individuals state such as hunger, sexual arousal, or anxiety and fear.<ref>Williams 2002, pp. 128</ref> Placing objects in reality from base shapes seen under influence from pscychotropics which link to [[Somatic symptom disorder|somatic]] physical responses lead now to full hallucinations. The relation between the first stage entoptic image and later stage full hallucinations are not mutually exclusive, both may be present.
===Stage 3=== Stage 3 images become iconic, relating to themes from the subjects life and become linked to powerful emotional experiences.<ref>Williams 2002, pp. 129</ref> Metaphor and simile give way to the belief that objects are exactly what they appear to be "subject losing insight into the differences between literal and analogical meanings"<ref>Williams 2002, pp. 128</ref> These stages may not always be sequential, and all stages may not be experienced depending on the subject and of course the type of psychotropic being used.
Williams notes that altered states are and their resulting impact on human [[consciousness]] is often marginalized within state, scientific, and religious realms.<ref>Williams 2002, pp. 121</ref> "The contemporary Western emphasis on the supreme value of intelligence has tended to suppress certain forms of consciousness and to regard them as irrational, marginal,aberrant or even pathological and thereby to eliminate them from investigations of the deep past."<ref>Williams 2002, pp. 121</ref> As with any well rounded approach to cultural or historical study, all aspects of the human condition must be explored, especially when such exploration takes us outside of our usual cultural perspective.
==See also== *[[Entheogen]] *[[Optical illusions]] *[[Phosphene]] *[[Psychedelic art]]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==References== *Lewis-Williams, D.J., 2002. The Mind In The Cave: Consciousness And The Origins Of Art. Thames & Hudson, London. * Dronfield, J. 1995. “Subjective Visions and the Source of Irish Megalithic Art.” in ''Antiquity'' 69, pp539–549 *Lewis-Williams, D. and Pearce, D. 2005. ''Inside the Neolithic Mind''. London: Thames and Hudson

{{Infobox person | name = Fanny Battle | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Mary Frances Battle | birth_date = {{Birth date|1842|09|24}} | birth_place = Cane Ridge, [[Tennessee]], [[United States]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1924|09|24|1842|09|24}} | death_place = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], United States | nationality = American | other_names = | occupation = [[Spy]]
[[Social reformer]] | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }} '''Fannie Battle''' (1842-1924) (born '''Mary Frances Battle''') was an American [[social reform|social reformer]] and former [[spy]] for the [[Confederate Army]]. ==A Spy for the Confederate Army== Battle was born in 1842 in Cane Ridge near [[Nolensville, Tennessee]].{{cite web |title=Fannie Battle Day Home Records, ca. 1905 - ca. 1998 (bulk 1905 - 19 72 ) |url=http://findingaids.library.nashville.org/Special_Collections_Division_Finding_Aid_Fannie_Battle.pdf |website=Finding Aids |publisher=Nashville Public Library |accessdate=5 October 2018}} She attended the [[Nashville Female Academy]]. Her three brothers and father enlisted in the [[Confederate Army]] at the start of the [[American Civil War]].{{cite web |last1=Bucy |first1=Carole Stanford |title=Mary Frances "Fannie" Battle |url=https://tennesseeencyclopedia.net/entries/mary-frances-battle/ |website=Tennessee Encyclopedia |publisher=Tennessee Historical Society |accessdate=5 October 2018}}{{cite web |last1=West |first1=Mike |title=Fannie Battle: Confederate ‘spy’ turned social reformer |url=https://www.murfreesboropost.com/community/fannie-battle-confederate-spy-turned-social-reformer/article_67134df9-af93-564c-947f-0c26e8ff3a54.html |website=The Murfreesboro Post |accessdate=5 October 2018 |language=en}} Her father, Joel Allen Battle, started a company in Nolensville, called the "Zollicoffer Guards." It eventually became the [[20th Tennessee Infantry]] and Battle became captain. He would eventually serve as a Colonel. He was a prisoner of war and two of Battle's brothers were killed in the [[Battle of Shiloh]]. Battle joined the Confederacy as a [[spy]] when the [[Union Army]] occupied Nashville in March 1862. She joined alongside her sister-in-law, Harriet Booker. Battle entered Nashville with a fake Federal pass, traveling in and out of the city, gathering information about the Union Army's work in the area and smuggling medicine and other supplies out of the city. On April 7, 1863, Battle and Booker were arrested for smuggling and holding fake Federal passes. They were first detained at the [[Tennessee State Penitentiary]] and then they were moved to [[Camp Chase]] in [[Ohio]]. Shortly thereafter, they were transferred to the [[Old Capitol Prison]] in Washington, D.C., where five other female Confederate spies were held. Battle and Booker were released on May 13, 1863 in [[City Point, Virginia]]. Battle returned to Nashville and started teaching at Howard School. She taught math, geography and spelling throughout Nashville until 1886. ==Social reformer== In December 1881, the [[Cumberland River]] flooded. Battle met with Nashville leadership and organized the Nashville Relief Society to help poor flood victims living in flood zones near the river. Over 1,000 people were provided clothing, food and coal. As a result, Battle worked with other local leaders to create United Charities. The organization struggled to secure funding to hire an executive director. Therefore, Battle quit her job teaching in 1886 and served as the nonprofit's secretary-general, a position she would hold until her death in 1924. During her work with United Charities, Battle created a [[daycare]] program for the children of working parents. She rented a room in a neighborhood in North Nashville, located near [[cotton mills]] that employed women mill workers. Physicians and other professionals provided pro bono services to the growing number of children in the program. Eventually, the program was named the Addison Avenue Day Home, the first daycare in Nashville. Today, it is named the Fannie Battle Day Home for Children. In 1900, Battle created a [[summer camp]] for low-income mothers and their children. Located in [[Craggie Hope, Tennessee|Craggie Hope]], it was named the Fresh Air Camp. Sixteen years later, Battle created a fundraising campaign for the Day Home, during which [[carolers]] would perform during the [[Christmas]] holiday. ==Death and legacy== Battle died in September 1924. Memorial services were held at [[McKendree United Methodist Church]]. She was buried at [[Mt. Olivet Cemetery (Nashville)|Mt. Olivet Cemetery]]. After Battle's death, the Addison Avenue Day Home was renamed the Fannie Battle Day Home for Children. In 1947, Battle's service in the Confederate Army was memorialized with a plaque at the [[Confederate Museum]]. The archives of Battle, and a portrait of her, are held in the [[Nashville Public Library]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{findagrave|9045551}} *[http://www.fanniebattle.org/ Fannie Battle Day Home for Children]] *[http://tnportraits.org/battle-mary-f-fannie-metro.htm Painting of Fannie Battle] in the collection of the Nashville Public Library [[Category:1924 deaths]] [[Category:1842 births]] [[Category:Social reformers]] [[Category:Female wartime spies]] [[Category:American Civil War spies]] [[Category:Confederate States of America military personnel]] [[Category:People of Tennessee in the American Civil War]]
